awd_titl_txt: Conference: The 15th U.S.-Korea Forum on Nanotechnology: Nanomedicine focusing on Single Cell level and Internet of Things including Nanosensors, July 12-13 2018, Ilsan, Korea
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed project for a Forum seeks financial to support scientist and engineer participation in the The 15th U.S.-Korea Forum on Nanotechnology: Nanomedicine focusing on Single Cell level and Internet of Things including Nanosensors to be held July 12-13, 2018 in Ilsan, Korea. The Forum will host 8 senior presenters and 7 additional early-career presenters and an approximately equal number of Korean presenters. It will actively encourage partnerships in nanotechnology for breakthroughs in various topics in nanomedicine focusing on single cell level as well as IoT including nanosensors. 

The participants will address issues related to the understanding of toxicity and environmental impact of nanomaterials. The meeting will encourage research collaboration and exchange on various aspects of nanomedicine including integration of nanomaterials with biology, development of diagnostic devices, contrast agents, analytical tools, physical therapy applications, and drug delivery vehicles. It will also address cutting-edge IoT devices with nanosensors and nanoactuators and massively-distributed networks. 

Post-doctoral researchers will be considered as qualified early-career researchers to present posters and promote in this way further research collaboration among young scientists in both countries. Collaboration possibilities will be intensively pursued by active participation in discussions throughout the Workshop. The forum proceedings and findings will be published on Carnegie Mellon's website and will be available to a broad audience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report:

The 15th US-Korea Forum on Nanotechnology:

Nanomedicine focusing on Single Cell level and

 Internet of Things including Nanosensors

PI: Myung S. Jhon, Carnegie Mellon

co-PI: Elias Towe, Carnegie Mellon

Ahmed Busnaina, Northeastern University

Mamadou Diallo, California Institute of Technology

 

We organized the 15th nanotechnology Forum between the US and Korea, to explore the topics on nanomedicine focusing on single cell level and Internet of Things (IoT) including nanosensors, on July 11th & 12th, 2018 in Ilsan, Korea. The delegates at the 5th meeting of the US-Korea Joint Committee on Scientific and Technological Cooperation (held on October 30th & 31st, 2002 in Seoul, Korea) agreed that the establishment of a US-Korea Forum on Nanotechnology would be beneficial to enhance research collaboration in the field of nanotechnology among scientists and engineers from both countries. With this mission, we established the 1st US-Korea Forum on nanotechnology, via National Science Foundation (NSF) funding, on October 14th -18th of 2003, in Seoul and continued for the past fourteen years. Participation was also overseen and funded by the Korea Ministry of Science and ICT, which is the Korean counterpart to NSF.

During this Forum, we empowered a common platform for scientists and engineers from both countries to accommodate urgent technology contribution on nanosensors for IoT devices and nanomedicine. Furthermore, to increase publicity, 15th Forum was planned as a satellite session of NanoKorea 2018 (http://sympo.nanokorea.or.kr/2018) for the first time. Eight senior oral presenters and seven additional junior poster presenters from US as well as twelve senior oral presenters and fifteen additional junior poster presenters from Korea participated. The Forum proceedings and findings are published on Carnegie Mellon website and are available to a broad audience. (http://www.cmu.edu/nanotechnology-forum/Forum_15GeneralInfo.htm.) We actively encouraged research collaborations by identifying topics and collaborative teams and partnership in the field of nanotechnology convergence to generate massive impact in nanoscience to strengthening achievements and assessing the progress based on our Forum’s recommendations. We aimed to provide maximum opportunities to young scientists as well as encouraging participation from diverse group.

The Intellectual Merits include:

(i)    Providing a common platform for researchers and innovators who are working on the leading edge of nanomedicine and IoT devices including nanosensors, and

(ii)   Simulating efforts to promote the above two areas for the next generation by fully utilizing nanotechnology convergence to bio-information-cognitive technology. The outcome for these timely topics leads to the establishment of milestone for the nanotechnology convergence.

The Broader Impacts include:

(i)    Bringing new paradigms in these fields and promoted collaborative initiatives between the two countries as well as constructing policy roadmap,

(ii)   Contributing to society, the global environment and economy in a broader sense by focusing on emerging technologies critical to the 4th industrial revolution,

(iii) Promoting the exchange of researchers between the two countries, especially strongly encouraging the collaboration among young scientists, and

(iv)  Initiating global collaborative interactions by identifying teams for specific projects. 

 


Last Modified: 06/27/2019
Modified by: Myung S Jhon
